Short lived climate forcers and aviation
Aviation’s net warming effect results from its historical and current emissions of CO
emissions of water vapour, soot, sulphur dioxide (from sulphur in the fuel), and nitrogen oxides (NO
(Penner et al. 1999; Lee et al. 2021; Naik et al. 2021)
from historic aviation emissions is not currently the largest forcing term, it is

mitigation of aviation to ‘net zero’ levels, as required in 1.5 ºC emission scenarios, requires fundamental
ogy, fuel types, or changes of behaviour or demand.
effects of aviation on climate fall into the category of short
currently result in net positive warming from the formation of short
(warming) and the destruction of ambient methane (cooling). If the conditions are suitable, emissions

SLCFs is estimated to be approximately 66% of aviation’s current total forcing. It is important to
note that the fraction of non
forcing to total forcing is not a fixed quantity and is dependent on the

Mitigation potential of fuels, operations, energy efficiency, and market
Technology options for engine and airframe:
For every kg of jet fuel combusted, 3.16
Engine and airframe manufacturers’ primary objective, after safety issues, is to reduce direct operating
costs, which are highly dependent on fuel burn. Large investments have gone into engine technology
step changes in engine technology over time, from early turbojet engines, to larger turbofan engines.
However, the basic configuration of an aircraf
t has remained more or less the same for decades and will
. Airframes performance has improved over the
wing design, but large incremental gains have become much harder as the technology
aisle aircraft, generally used for long ranges, fuel
burn is a pressing concern and
. The principal opportunities for fuel reduction come from improvements in aerodynamic
nd propulsion system improvements. In the future,
suggest that the highest rate of fuel burn reduction achiev
able for new aircraft is likely to be no
more than about 1.3% per year, which is well short of ICAO’s aspirational goal of 2% global annual
average fuel efficiency improvement. Radically different aircraft shapes, like the blended wing body
